snippet: Apple took Samsung to court in a patent case with broad implications for technology innovations, and a brokerage firm’s costly software malfunction cast further doubt on high-frequency trading.

headline.main: The Week’s Business News in Pictures

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes a 3-D printer providing a custom aid for a child with a rare disorder, reports of battery problems with a new Ma...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes a 3-D printer providing a custom aid for a child with a rare disorder, reports of battery problems with a new Macintosh operating system and undersea research bases.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: 'Magic Arms' and Never Starting Cable TV

snippet: Calls for stronger regulations of the computer-driven markets were renewed after the third stock trading catastrophe in the past five months. A look back on our reporting of the past week's highs and lows in finance.
abstract: Calls for stronger regulations of the computer-driven markets were renewed after the third stock trading catastrophe in the past five months. A look back on our reporting of the past week's highs and lows in finance.

headline.main: Week in Review: Calls for Change to a Complex Market

abstract: A new day of testimony in the dispute between Apple and Samsung began with a history lesson on the iPhone from Apple’s Philip W. Schiller.

headline.main: Apple's Schiller Testifies in Smartphone Patent Trial

snippet: Less hospital noise improves patient care, a complex Wells Fargo security goes wrong for investors, why prepaid phones aren't more popular and other consumer-focused news from today's Times.
abstract: Less hospital noise improves patient care, a complex Wells Fargo security goes wrong for investors, why prepaid phones aren't more popular and other consumer-focused news from today's Times.

headline.main: Friday Reading: Less Hospital Noise Improves Patient Care

snippet: Sony reported a loss of 24.6 billion yen for the April-to-June quarter and lowered its full-year earnings forecast. It has posted losses for four straight years.
abstract: Sony reports fiscal first-quarter loss of 24.6 billion yen ($315 million), compared with a 15.5 billion yen loss in the year-ago quarter; revenue rose 1.4 percent to 1.52 trillion yen ($19.4 billion); lowers its earnings forecast for its fiscal year ending in March 2013 to 20 billion yen ($256 million), down from 30 billion yen.

headline.main: Sony Cites Weak LCD Sales and a Strong Yen in Its Loss
headline.print_headline: Sony Cites Weak LCD Sales And a Strong Yen in Its Loss

snippet: “Joan Miró,” with 160 or so works from 1917 to 1974, is a beautiful and exciting show at the National Gallery of Art.
abstract: Ken Johnson reviews exhibit Joan Miro: The Ladder of Escape at the National Gallery of Art.

headline.main: Filtering Miró’s Work Through a Political Sieve
headline.print_headline: Filtering Miró’s Work Through a Political Sieve

snippet: Pummeled by the slow global economy, exchange rate shifts and the euro zone crisis, Sony reported a 77 percent slide in operating profit, far below expectations for the quarter.

headline.main: Sony's Quarterly Profit Sinks, Hit by Weak Demand
headline.print_headline: Sony's Quarterly Profit Sinks, Hit by Weak Demand
